animalOfTheDay.name: sandpiper
facts: They perform elaborate aerial displays during courtship.
Sandpipers have specialized bills that can sense vibrations of prey underground.
Some species undertake incredible migrations, flying nonstop for days over open ocean.
Sandpipers are shorebirds with long bills for probing sand and mud for food.

calendar.name: robin
facts: Robins are known for their red breasts, which are brighter in males during breeding season.
They are territorial and will aggressively defend their feeding areas in winter.
Robins sing year-round, with males using song to establish territory and attract mates.
They are one of the first birds to sing at dawn, earning them the nickname 'the early bird.'

calendar.name: rook
facts: Rooks are highly social corvids that nest in large colonies called rookeries.
They are among the most intelligent birds and can use simple tools.
They form lifelong pair bonds and often stay with the same mate for life.
Rooks have pale, featherless faces that distinguish them from other crows.

calendar.name: rottweiler
facts: They are powerfully built dogs with a natural guarding instinct.
Rottweilers were one of the first police dogs and are still used in K-9 units today.
Despite their tough appearance, they are affectionate with their families.
Rottweilers are descended from Roman war dogs and were used to herd cattle.

calendar.name: sable
facts: They are solitary animals with large territories that they mark with scent.
Sables are small, agile members of the weasel family with luxurious fur.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting both in trees and water.
Sables were once nearly hunted to extinction for their valuable fur.

calendar.name: salmon
facts: Salmon are anadromous, meaning they migrate from saltwater to freshwater to spawn.
They use Earth's magnetic field and smell to navigate back to their birthplace.
After spawning, most Pacific salmon die, while some Atlantic salmon may survive to spawn again.
Salmon are a keystone species, providing nutrients to forests when their carcasses decompose.

calendar.name: sand dollar
facts: When alive, they are covered in tiny, velvety spines that help them move and feed.
They feed by filtering tiny particles of food from the sand using their tube feet.
Sand dollars are flat sea urchins that live on the ocean floor.
The five-petal pattern seen on dead sand dollars is actually their skeletal structure.

calendar.name: sandpiper
facts: Sandpipers have specialized bills that can sense vibrations of prey underground.
They perform elaborate aerial displays during courtship.
Some species undertake incredible migrations, flying nonstop for days over open ocean.
Sandpipers are shorebirds with long bills for probing sand and mud for food.

randomAnimals.name: hoopoe
facts: The hoopoe is a bird from Europe, Asia, and Africa, known for its characteristic, fan-like crest on its head and a long, curved beak.
Its name comes from its distinctive 'hoo-poo' call.
Hoopoes feed on insects and larvae, which they extract from the ground and crevices using their beak.
Female hoopoes secrete a foul-smelling substance from a gland near their tail to deter predators from the nest.

randomAnimals.name: wild yak
facts: Wild yaks are large cattle from Asia, inhabiting the high, cold plateaus of Tibet and the Himalayas.
Their droppings are often used as fuel by local communities.
They have long, thick fur that helps them survive in extreme temperatures.
They are herd animals, living in groups, and their roar is often heard in the mountains.

randomAnimals.name: civet
facts: They are omnivorous, eating fruits, insects, small mammals, and birds.
Kopi Luwak coffee, one of the most expensive coffees in the world, is produced from beans that have been digested and excreted by civets.
Most species are nocturnal and arboreal, although some are more terrestrial.
Civets are cat-like mammals from Africa and Asia, known for their ability to secrete a musky scent, used in perfumery.
